div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Railways Express Service for Vienna, Paris, and London.
*Special express Itinerary arriving Piraeus Friday evenings and Constantinople Saturday afternoons omitting Smyrna and Mitylene outwards.

The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrount in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakehlieh and Kossier leave Suez alternatly on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah; continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN.
For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager – – R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
FRIDAY, JUNE 21, 1907

div.head: TROUBLES IN FRANCE
div.p: The telegrams we publish today show no diminution in the anarhy prevailing in the South of France. The wine-growers and the people dependent upon them number about two and a half millions. Montpellier, the centre of the whole movement, is a small provincial town. Yet within the space of a day it was called upon to give hospitality to at least three-quarters of a million souls, who had gathered to protest against the French Government's non-alleciation of distress. The outcome of that meeting has had an extraordinary result. M. Marcellin Albert, who has been styled the 'Messiah of the Midi,' so influenced the gathering that it pledged itself to hold together to the last, and to defend the wine industry by every means in its power.

Following upon this general declatation came the announcement that the South of France viticulteurs would pay no taxes until their grivances had been promised redress. That reminds us of our passive-resistance crusade at home, but the French are impulsive, and were not even satisfied with their determination not to contribute to the revenue. Therefore they gave definitiveness to their movement by planning the collapse of the whole machinery of local government in the districts affected. The fact that this was no mere piece of effervescent emotionalist is corroborated by the news that the municipalities have resigned and the municipal employees have struck work.

The Southern revolt has reached a crisis, violence is feared, and troops are being drafted into the area affected. The population's strike – for it is nothing less – has been accompanied with some dramatic scenes. At Narbonne the Mayor dissolved the municipal body at sunset, the church bells and the fire-station having been employed to sound the tocsin. On the balcony of the Town Hall, Councillor after Councillor removed his insignia and threw it into the Market-place. The tricolour was torn from the flagstaff, and its place was taken by a large black flag. In face of this action, the French Government appears to be paralysed. It cannot remedy the distress by the negative means advised. Vine growers are, of course, starving amid their fruitful vineyards. But the fault is not to be laid against the Government, but to economic causes. Fraud, adulteration, and grape subsitutes made from sugar, and are, therefore, met by opposition from the beet-sugar growers, who fear the shutting down of their market. Thus, there is no prospect of effecting a speedy cure for the distresses of the people of the Midi.

div.head: EGYPTIAN RULERS SPRING-CLEANED
div.p: Of course, it is quite right and proper that the Egyptians at the British Museum should be spring-cleaned. But it stikes one as rather unseemly that they should be spring-cleaned like ordinary mortals, as through they had not existed some thousands of years ago, before pure water and fresh air had become such a mania as at present. A Nile was the least we could offer them for their ablutions, and for a towel – white samite is the only material that sounds imposing enough. And yet it is to be feared that a pail, a cake of yellow soap, and and the common pump, or tap, are more probable than all these. Perhaps the British Museum authorities have something saponaceous, more in the style of ambrosia – there is no term for "soap for the gods." For one cannot think that Isis and Osiris or Thothmes or Rameses could be submitted to the indignity of the ordinary cleansing process, which might just as well be applied to any schoolboy.

div.head: Materieh Relief Fund.
div.p: The total sum collected up to date, for the inhabitants of Matarieh amounts to £22,394,

div.head: Mediterranean Fleet
div.p: The Mediterranean Meet is expected to arrive at Alexandria on the 28th inst.

div.head: Mariout Inspection
div.p: Mr. Machell has arrived at Cairo after his inspection of the Mariout district. The Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior visited the various police posts and was entertained to lunch by the Khedive at El Menaonleh.

div.head: Attack on Mr. Cuy.
div.p: The native who, without any provocation, savagely attacked Mr. Guy, dragoman of the french Agency, in the Esbekieh some weeks ago. a report of which we published, has been sentenced by the Native Tribunal to three months' imprisonment.

div.head: The Credit Fonoler Winner.
div.p: A native housepainter, of the name of Saad Chehawi, was the winner of the latest "groslot" ot the Crédit Foncier (new issue). The lucky winner ot the 50,000 francs lives at Karmons. He was purchasing the share by monthly payments and had only paid for a few months.

div.head: Alexandria Sporting Club.
div.p: The Alexandria Sporting Club will hold a a Gymkhana on Saturday the 29th inst. on the occasion of the arrival of the Mediterranean fleet, which is due at Alexandria on Friday the 28th. The programme will he published in the "Egyptian Gazette" early next week.

div.head: Fatal Accidents.
div.p: A native, named Ali Mohamed Saleh, while working on the permanent way at El Zamalek yesterday, was crushed by a locomotive of the Delta Light Railways. Death was instantaneous. On Wednesday last a small boy, named Abil el Ahmed, fell from the balcony of his parents home at Dabiblia into the street and succombed to his injuries on the way to hospital.

div.head: A Street Brawl
div.p: A great disturbance arose last night in the Rue d'Allemagne, Alexandria. Three Italians, who were somewhat inebriated, insisted on taking a cab The cabmen refused as he did not like their condition. They insisted, a squabble ensued, and soon a great crowd of natives gathered together from all parts. The Italians were maltreated and eventually they and the cabman were arrested. It was half an hour before any shawish or ghaffir appeared on the scene of the quarrel, though the commotion caused by it was considerable.

div.head: Khédivial School of Law.
div.p: The rumours of a serious dissension having arisen between Mr. D. Dunlop, Adviser to the Ministry of Education, and Mr. E. Lambert, Principal , of the Khédivial School of Law, which appeared in several of our native contemporaries yesterday are, we are glad to say, entirely without foundation. The relations existing between the School of Law and the Ministry are, and always have been, of the most eordial naturel and the report that an attempt was made to prevent Mr. Lambert taking his well merited leave of absence is quite incorrect. Mr. E. Lambert has left Cairo for Alexandria.

div.head: Excitement at Athens
div.p: A telegram was received at Alexandria last night from Athens by the Greek journal "Byzantios" announcing that a bomb was thrown into the midst of the Parliament yesterday morning at a moment when Mr. Simopnulos was diseusssing the budget. The bomb was thrown at Mr. Kyriaco Mavro michalis, the member for Oetulou. Fortunately the bomb did not explode. The miscreant, who threw it, was at once arrested. His name is Papainicropoulos Great excitement prevails at Athens.

div.head: Franciscan Missionaries.
div.p: The annual distribution of prizes took place on Tuesday ofthe S.S. Franciscan Missionaries of Rue Nebi Daniel The programme was a varied one and consisted of three comedies, recitations, songs, and pianoforte duets The French comedy —"La Belle, au hois dormant" was acted well, the-original parts being taken by Misses Benno, Nuzzolese.and Ckoukry. The Italian comedy was most amusing. The principal parts were well sustained by Misses Grech, Cassimate, and Nuzzolese. The English comedy "Red Riding Hood" was very pretty and the principals parts were taken by Misses N. Purvis, N. Roberts, D. Shellard, L. Orsi, and R. Gauci. Great credit is due to their teacher, Miss K. Twoney, of the Berlitz school. The recitation "II Soldato Italiano" was well done by M. Costanti also "Anticagliae Novità" was well recited by Misses R. Gauci and X uzzolese. The performance by the four little hoys, which was brilliantly accompanied-by Miss L. Orsi, caused great mirth, Edgar Roberts, André Fergiman, Alberto Fabre, and R. Kanah, each playing different instruments as musicians ; it was certainly the most amusing piece of the performance. Miss Ns Purvis accompanied several pieces, and her careful playing showed her to be a very good pianist for her age. Miss Cesana accompanied the sung "Won't you buy my pretty flowers," which was prettily sung by Mias Nanine Roberts, and her sweet voice gives great prepare for the future. Miss Choukry and Miss Purvi ; dosed the programme with a pianoforte duet. Among those present were Marches di Soragana, Consul General of Italy, the Rev. Archbishop of Alexandria, Rev. Father Holland and all the clergy of St Catherines, Comm. Verifcà, Grafton Bey, Mr. J. E. Roberts, Mr. Spurgeon, Master L. Sarjeant, Mr. Orsi, and many others.

div.head: CASSA SUSPENDS PAYMENT
div.p: SIR E. CASSELL AND UNION BANK
ALEXANDRIA BOURSE CLOSED

The worse has come to the worst and the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio at Alexandria and Cairo has closed its doors. The scene in the purlieus of the Alexandria Bourse was peculiarly animated this morning ; agitated groups of every race and kind discussed the situation and all sorts of rumours were bruited about. The members of the Committee of the Alexandria Stock and Sharebrokers Associations hastily assembled and came to the decision that in view of the extreme gravity of the situation extraordinary measures must be imperatively taken. The Association therefore decided that the stock and share Bourse of Alexandria should be closed and that it should not be opened again until the situation of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio had been accurately determined. This momentous step was taken because it was feared that if business was conducted as usual this morning, the closing of the Bank would lead to a heavy fall all round owing to panic stricken sellers throwing vast quantities of securities on the market. Owing to the continuous fall, the scarcity of buyers, and the general want of confidence that prevails, it was thought that an unprecedented catastrophe would ensue if the market remained open. The Bourse of Alexandria will he closed therefore until further notice.

The closing of the Alexandria Bourse is the sabject of diverse criticism. On th.e one hand 'the Committee are censured for having resorted So such an extreme measure, as it is considered that it will have a very bad effect on the opinion of London and Paris, and the money markets of Europe generally, which will at once jump to the conclusion that the state of Affairs is far more disastrous than it actually is and there will be a universal rush to get rid of Egyptian securities. On the other hand it is alleged that such a measure as the closing of the Bourse has often been resorted coin the cases of second-rate bourses, as for example, that of Constantinople, and as moreover sound financial opinion in London and Paris does not take the Alexandria Bourse very seriously, it does not really matter much one way or the other.

I The interest has been now shifted from Alexandria and Vienna to London. One of the directors of the Union Bank at Vienna Arrives at London this evening in order to confer with Sir Ernest Cassell and the important group interested in the National Bank of Egypt. Sir Ernest is interesting himself in the matter and the result of the deliberations, which are about to take place in London, will be anxiously awaited in Egypt.

The Chairman of the Board of. Directors of the Union Bank has left Vienna and is arriving at Alexandria by the Austrian Lloyd steamer, on Monday next. He will examine the position of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio.
The two following notices were posted on the door of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio at Alexandria this morning :

div.p: Cairo, 12.30 p m.

On the news of the closing of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio here this morning there was a run on Mosseri's Bank, as it was rumoured that the establishment was interested to a considerable extent in the Cassa.

div.head: BRITISH RIFLE CLUB (ALEX)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
div.p: At the second meeting of the fifth season of the Alexandria Swimming, which will be held tomorrow afternoon, a polo match between teams of H.M.S. Diana and the club will be played and will be followed by a team race of 420 yards, also Diana v. Club, each member of the teams swimming 60 yards. There will also be a 60 yards handicap for the members of the club. The club boat will leave the Marina for Ras-el-Tin lighthouse at 3.15 p.m.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB
div.p: On the occationof the visit of the British Squadron to this port at the end of the month, the Commodore and members of the Khedivial Yacht Club will give an "At Home" to the Officers of the Squardron, and a regatta will be given for the boats of the Fleet. The date proposed is Monday, July 1st from 4.0 to 6.30 p.m. and unless this date is altered no further notice will be issued.

div.head: LONDON STOCK EXCHANGE

LONDON, Friday.

The forced sale of Egyptian securities is still proceeding on the London Stock Exchange. The shares are being well taken in anticipation of an early recovery. It is expected that there will be a considerable rebound when the crisis is passed.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive attended the midday prayers today at Sidi Gaber Mosque, accompanied by Mustapha Ibadi Pasha.
Yesterday afternoon his Highness received in private audience Prince Kamal Eddin Pasha and Sir Eldon Gorst.
It is stated that the Khedive has despatched Aly Pasha Assaf on a special mission to the island of Thasos.

div.head: NOTES FROM BEYROUT.
div.p: Beyrouth, June 14, 1907.

The Russian Consul General Prine Gagarine and the Princess his wife arrived on Wednesday morning by the Russian mail steamer from Constantinople. By the same steamer arrived also Prince and Princess Tcherkowski. Prince Tcherkowski has just been appointed Russian Consul at Damascus where a few years previously he had been as vice-consul.

Madame Wassa Pasha widow of the late Governor of the Lebanon sailed this morning by the Messageries "Senegal" for Constantinople. A crowd of distinguished friends accompanied her on board with floral tributes. Madame Wassa Pasha has been for a few weeks a welcome guest at her friend's Madame Habib Dumani, and had come out to Beyrout with her two sons Selim and Said Bey to visit the tomb of her late husband, and see the land where she has been the object of so much honor. The many invitations she has from several distinguished people, both Christian and Druse, in the Lebanon, who had been known to the late Mutessarif, speak well for the latter's faithful and disinterested remembrance of past favours. It must be said that Madame Wassa by her charmingly unaffected and kind ways contributed also to the inspiration of such spontaneous welcome.

In the list of distinguished arrivals should certainly be included that of Madame Albert Fouques Duparc, the sympathetic wife of the highly esteemed French Consul General, who arrived this morning by the welcomed by a host of distinguished people and all the consular staff.

Miss Helen Gould, the celebrated American milliardiare and philanthropist, has during her recent visit to Beyrout after a trip in the Holy Land, been invited to the Syrian Protestant College. Miss Gould evinced a lively interest in this grand institution and in view of the friendship that exists between her and Mrs. Russell Sage, who lately endowed the College with the liberal sum of 50,000 dollars, it is hoped that a noble sense of emulation will divert thereto a part of the universal and immense charities to which this noble lady has been vowing her life and fortune.

By the death of the agent of the Russian Steam Navigation Company, Mr. Nicholas Catzeflis, a noble character prematurely disappeared. The deceased was distinguished by a fearless frankness and an uncompromising attitude towards sham traits that challenge particular notice in the smooth-tongued East. Despite a certain sourness that marked sometimes his demeanour, and that was caused by his chronic gastci trouble, his refined intelligence and sterling qualities won him a large circle of distinguished friends, as the imposing funeral attended by most of the Consuls General, testified. The late Mr. Catzeeflis was acting agent for the Russian Steam Navigation Company at Alexandria a few years, and the capable and scrupulous manner in which the helped the Customs authorities at that port to fight the subtle hasheesh contrabandists won him the esteen and sympathetic friendship of Chitty Bey, whose name will for ever live in the annals of the Egyptian Customs.

A suspected case of plague having occurred at Amsheet, a village a few miles to the North of Junieh, the well known port of the Lebanon, the Mutessarif Muzaffer Pasha wired to the Vali of Beyrout and the Board of Health at Constantinople accordingly. The Sanitary Inspector here delegated the Lazaretto doctor to the sport to make an examination of the case and report thereon. The result of this examination having been negative, culture and innoculation were resorted to by way of confirmatory evidence and we are pleased to state that a negative pronouncement has definitely been made. The incidence of the case under the circustances and at such a comperatively isolated village was calculated make one anticipate such a result.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Amasis sailed from Tripoli (Barbary) yesterday evening and is due here on Monday morning.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: A COMPANY'S SERIOUS POSITION.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, — The opinions, which you published in the "Gazette" of the 19th inst, on the position of the Company, whose parlous state is now causing a great deal of grave anxiety at Alexandria, should arouse the board of directors of that concern to a sense of their responsibilities. The Company in question is one of the very many, which have lately been floated in Egypt but registered in Loudon for the purpose of evading the regulations laid down by the Egyptian Government in respect of founders shares. The proposition of the directors to offer in settlement of their liability the cancellation of all operations in the shares, by the collection or payment of the difference on all transactions, basing the value at par, is absolutely inadmissible as the shares are now practically valtfefass. If the shareholders are so dead to their own interests as to permit of such a proposition they deserve no pity. The Company is an English one and amenable to the Companies Act, and ft will be therefore no difticult matter to set the law in motion in the British Consular Court at Alexandria. The subjects of other nations, benefiting by the- Capitulations, who abuse their privileges by keeping gambling hells or disorderly houses,have of late led Lord Cromer to demand the reform of the Capitulations. But these offences are venial compared with that of using the Capitulations to start English Companies, in order that the directors may evade their responsabilities, thereby bringing disaster on hundreds and thousands of unfortunate speculators and investors. The scandal of foisting English Companies on the Egyptian public has become very grave during the last few months. The Companies Act of 1900 may be very will suited for a country like England where the business and financial instincts of the people have been cultivated for centuries. But the liberty accorded by this Act is totally unsuited to Egypt, where there is a public, who know little of finance, bat who are impregnated with an extraordinarily keen love of gambling. An example should be made to show that the stringency of the Companies Act is as severely upheld in the British Consular Courts in Egypt as it is in the High Courts of Justice. The English are the trustees of Egypt and we should not permit the law of our own land to be used as a convenient cloak for unscrupulous company promoters and directors, at the expense of the ignorant inhabitants of Egypt In the case of the Company, which was the object of your animadversions, here is an excellent opportunity for showing Egypt that English Law cannot be treated with contempt by directors eager to evade their responsibilities. The law ought to be put in motion and the responsibilities brought home. It Will be an excellent precedent for other occasions in the near future.
Truly Yours,
An Investor.
Alexandria, June 20th.

div.head: BATHING AT CLEOPATRA.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Dear Sir,—I fully endorse the remarks made by "English resident" with regard to the bathing place at Cleopatra, but feel that he is doing the "Good Jesuit. Fathers" and their noble intentions too much honour, if for one moment he ventures to think that bathers might be detered, by notices or other impedimenta put up on the spot by the said "Good Fathers" from using the pool. Well, Sir, I for one, and with me several friends, have not thought it worth to take the slightest notice of the "Jesuit Fathers" warnings, be they in the shape of notices or white handkerchiefs. In fact, the only thing I regretted when the notice of the "charitable Fathers" struck my eyes, was that no pot of black paint and brush was at hand, when I should have written something across the "Notice Board" just to enlighten the "Good Jesuit Fathers" on the question of Christian Love and Charity. However, other hands were more radical and simply pulled the board down without further ado. And well they did. Of course, this only goes to show how manifold the ways are to do good "ad majorem Dei gloriam."
Faithfully yours,
F.R.
Halte Cleopatra, 19th June 1907

div.head: WHEN CAIRO SLEEPS
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette " Dear Sir,—It has long been in my mind to trespass on your kindness for the insertion of a complaint on a subject which, I am convinced, is a very general source of annoyance. I refer to the assemblies held by boabs every night at the doors of the premises whose well-being is fallaciously supposed to be their " raison d'être. " These assemblies generally last well into the small hours, and the unfortunate residents are afflicted with noisy discussions in the Berberine dialect which banish sleepand induce a fiendish desire for vengeance on the offenders. The abatement of this nuisance is a matter of considerable importance and it would be interesting to know how to set about it : same of the more vigorous members of the community abate it in.a summary manner with a thick stick, and are free from annoyance for a certain period, but this course is not to be recommended from a law abiding point of view, and a practical .solution is highly necessary, backed up by the power of the law It would be interesting to hear other peoples' views on the subject, but at the same time unless a practical result is arrived at the ventilation of opinions will be futile.
Thanking you for your courtesy.
Yours truly,
Sufferer.
Cairo, June 20th 1907.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser, is going on leave as soon as Lord Edward Cecil returns from Europe, that is in the first week of July.

Sir William Willcocks passed through Port Said on Wednesday on board the S.S. Kronprinz on his way to England. He has almost completely recovered from his serious illness and hopes to be back in Cairo in October. We have been requested by Sir William to thank his many friends who have enquired after him during his severe illness.

The Consul General of Norway, Mr. Henry Edward Barker, was received yesterday afternoon in private audience by the Khedive to take leave of his Highness prior to his departure for Europe and to present Mr. Herman Nielsen, who will act as Consul General during the absence of Mr. Barker.

Miss Iris Moberly Bell, daughter of Mr. Moberly Bell, manager and for many years Cairo correspondent, of the "Times", was married on Wednesday week to Mr. Charles Ernest Pumphrey, son of Mr. Joseph Pumphrey, of Minister Acres, Northumberland. The ceremony was performed at the Church of the Annunciation, Old Quebec Street, by Canon Edgar Sheppard, D.D., Sub-Dean of the Cliapels Royal, assisted by Canon Ottley and the Rev. R. R. Bell, cousin of the bride.

Among those, who left yesterday for Constantinople on the Khédivial S.S. "Osmanieh" were Hassan Bey Hassib, Moudir of Assouan, Mohamed Bey Shoubashi, and Mahmoud Bey Rechad, President of the Cairo native Court of First Instance.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh : Mr. and Mrs. G. A. Villforth and family, Mr. and Mrs. R. S. Beasley, Maître and Mrs. Simon, Dr. and Mrs. André Mantzonfas, Mr. and Mrs. W. Johnson, Mr. and Mrs. G Zahar, Mr. and Mrs. Ch. Bird, Mr. A. E. Halim, Mr. Limpritis. Mr. W. Malcolm, Miss Malcolm, Mrs. Miller and family, Mr. Otto Muller, Miss M. Cracken, Mr. and Mrs. H. Williams, Miss L. Scott, Mr. James Watson, Mr. and Mrs. G. H Lawson, Captain and Mrs. Cummins, Mr. and Mrs. II. Bevan.

div.head: EGYPTIAN RULERS
div.p: UNDERGOING SPRING-CLEANING

Following upon the sacrilegious invasion of the studiouR calm ot the British Museum reading-room by the brush and scraper of the decorator, which sent a sad troop of disconsolate literary "ghosts" wandering in the outer wilderness, the spring-cleaning charwoman or charman has laid an unwonted hand upon the Court of the Egyptian kings.

Yesterday the aspect of the gloomy gallery was strange and ununsual. It is the mission in life of the spring-cleaner, male or female, to track down dirt and dust and to eradicate them with an unsparing and vandal hand.

The result.proves that a liberal application of pure water is as good for Egyptian relics as for more modern articles. Those who visit the Egyptian Court in future will observe on the granite countenance of the colossal head of Thothmes III., who was King of Egypt a mat ter of 3,500 years ago, a blush of health and the suspicion of a granite smile not previously noticeable. Sekhet, the fire goddess and the "Smiter of the Anti," can now be seen in all the beauty of her highly-polished black granite. Most of the effigies of this goddess, who is generally represented holding the "symbol of life," are in black granite, and the virtue that lies in a good wash is particularly noticeable in her case.

The monuments of the Egyptian kings and deities, that lend such grim solemnity to this section of the museum, have long been accused of uncleanliness They carry the incrustation of the dust of the desert, which has been a cumulating since the world was young, and which has been considerably added to since they took up their dwelling in London. Travellers declare that the monuments that are retained in Egypt are considerably cleaner than those in this country This stigma is now being removed, and the grime of centuries is beginning to fall from the shoulders of Hathor, the "Queen of all the gods j" from Menthu-ra, the "dwellerin Thebes from Hapi, the "god of the Nile," and from Isis, Osiris, and Amen ra, Rameses, Amenhetep, and other Egyptian potentates, who have slept too long in their cloaks of dirt, are beginning to be seen in new and unsuspected colours, and the hieroglyphics that adorn the granite sarcophagi are becoming vastly more intelligible to earnest Egyptologists

div.head: CYPRUS TILES FOR EGYPT
div.p: The first export of perforated bricks from Cyprus to Egypt has taken place this week, the Ceramic Company of Limassol (Sooiété Anonyme Céramique) having just despatched 300,000 of these bricks to Alexandria. A large part of these bricks have been ordered from Egypt. These bricks are very light and are of great use for the upper stories of houses. Up to now these bricks have been imported into Egypt from Marseilles but it is hoped in Cyprus that there will soon develop a large export from Limassol. The Company have begun to manufacture French tiles with a view to export. The quality of the work turned out from the Limassol factory is excellent and owiug to the1 cheap freights by sailing craft from Cyprus to Alexandria, the Company will be able to successfully compete with the European impoiters.

div.head: LORD DUNDOALD'S RETIREMENT
div.p: A REMARKABLE EXPLANATION

The Earl of Dundonald, in an interview with the "Daily Mail," made the following statement of the reasons for his sudden retirement from the anny, which was announced in our special telegram of the 12th inst. :—

"Why have I retired ? Well, I liave not retired voluntarily from the Army, in which I have served since I was a boy of seventeen. 1 have not retired on account of old age, for I liave still some thirteen years before the age clause would affect me in my present rank. I have not retired because the Promotion Board did not think me worthy of promotion, for I was promoted last year.

" I have retired simply because the British authorities have offered me no employment since I was turned out—yes, I prefer the words 1 turned ont —from the Canadian Militia for ealling attention to political corruption in the appointment of officers—corruption that, if not protested against by someone, would be bound to destroy the efficiency of that fine body of men. For I consider unfairness and favouritism is bound to destroy efficiency and take the heart out of any military force."

div.head:
LONDON PICTURE EXHIBITION
EGYPT PAST AND PRESENT
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
London, June 13, 1907

Lovers of Egypt and scenes Egyptian should not miss the unique opportunity that is now being presented at Messers. McLeans' galleries of picking up at a moderate price some charming mementoes of the land of the Pharaohs. Miss Hadden and Miss McCracken both shew an intimate acquaintance with their subject, and their pictures reveal the true spirit of the East, without being marred by the meretricious gaudiness which so ofter stamps this calss of work, being soft in tone and not too high in colouring. Miss Hadden has confined herself almost entirely to animals, and with no little success, notably in (20).

"Types of Cairo Donkeys" and (27). A "study in expression," this latter being in our opinion a unique bit of animal portraiture. She would seem to be more successful where she treats heads only, than where she takes in the whole animal, this being due perhaps to an inadequate study of anatomy. Nos. (25) and (26) are worthy of special mention, being paintings of Hathor, Mistress of the West painted by permission in the Cairo Museum. She has not confined herself entirely to Egyptian subjects and we cannot resist mentioning her picture of Penguins at the London Zoo, which displays a keen sense of humour as well ss an accurate eye for bird life in the artist. Miss McCracken has confined herself to scenes in town and on the river banks, and of her pictures we can but praise the general level of excellence of them all ; they speak to one ot the East without being, if we may be pardoned the phrase, offensively Eastern. There is neither exaggeration nor glare about them. If we had to select any particular one for praise our choice fall on (32) Brass Bazaar, Cairo, but all are exclient and the show as a whole is well worth a visit from anyone who loves Egypt and appreciates a faithful depiction of its charms.

div.head: MISSION WORK AMONG SYRIANS
div.p: The annual meeting of the Archbishop's Mission to the Assyrian Christians was held last week at Lambeth Palace. The Archbishop of Canterbury, who presided, said that this movement aimed, not at converting peoglé to our mode of faith, but at strengthening and restoring perhaps the most ancient Christian community in the world. The outlook had never been so hopeful as now. These people were on both sides of the frontier, and now more on the Turkish than on the Persian side. The mission's work at Urmi was, therefore, being transferred to Van. There were interesting movements in connexion with Oriental Churches generally which made it specially desirable to strengthen the work at the centre of this mission. In India there were certainly 500,000 Syrian Christians, now divided into discordant and contending sects ; and their best men were seeking Anglican co-operation in arranging that their episcopal life should be under the guidance of a Bishop ordained by the Patriarch, with whom this mission was working. It was a difficult and complicated question, but a report made by the Rev. W.H. Browne, of this mission, on his visit to the Syrians in India gave great hope of suocess. The mission's work was also becoming better understood by other bodies of Oriental Christians. That great body, the Jacobite Church, was feeling its way towards getting some guidance and stimulus from the Anglicans. At his request, the Rev. O.H. Parry, the outgoing head of the mission, had been visiting the Jacobite authorities and discussing possibilities. The Armenians, too, were discussing the question of possible intercommunion. Those who had studied the questioA would say that a good many of the Oriental sects owed their independence rather to national sympathies and characteristics than to any determined adherenoe to heretical or doubtful creeds or usages. This mission should be recognized as not merely keeping on their legs a folk who would otherwise collapse, but an setting forward the great cause of unity in the Church of Christ The importance of the work was altogether out of proportion to the funds.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutingny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Lundi 17 Juni.
Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres, que
nous avions laisse it 3 3/4, s'est eleve successivement veudredi passte a 3 7/8 et samedi a 4 pour cent, soit en hausse de 1,4.
Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a baisse avant-hier de 1/8 83 7/8. L'Unifiee

est remontee de 1/4 a 104 1/4. La National Bank a encore perdu 1/4 de livre a 19 1/2, de meme que laDai'ra Sanieh a 13 1/4. L'Agricole a regagne 1/4 a 7 3/4. La Delta Light a ega- lement repris 3/8 a 9 1/2.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a en­core recute de 5 francs a 684 et la Banque d'A- thenes de 6 francs a 116.

Ici, le marche a repris, ce matin, une phy- sionomie convenable, sinon tout a fait regnliere. La seance a bien encore ete ouvertepar un discours, mais court et nullement dans le genre de ceux qui avaient marque lesjouritees de jeudi et vendredi derniers. De plus, ce speech a officiel, prononce par le president interimaire de l'honorable Corporation des agents de change. Stir un ton onctuenx et pa­terae, M. Paul Oziol a engage ces messieurs de la corbeille a ne pas se laisser influencer par les nouvelles pessimistes repandues par les bais- siers sur le compte d'une seciete fonciere et d'un etablissement de banque, nouvelles qne le president de la Corporation a declarees po- sitivement fausses. M. Paul Oziol a termine sa harangue par quelques bonnes paroles prechant la concorde etl'union, voire la " cooperation a l'ceuvre commune. "

Nous allions oublier de dire que, d'ordre du Comite, la duree des seances a ete fixee a une heure, au lieu d'une demie. Toutes les opera- rations pratiquees sont de nouveau enregis- trdes. Les teneurs de carnet ont ete finalement exclus de la corbeille jusqu'a nouvel ordre,
etc., etc.

Toutes ces decisions sont diversement com­mentees. Reconnaissons qu'elles n'.emeuvent profondement personne, par suite de leur ca- ractfcre febrile. L'opinion prevaut, d'ailleurs, que le Comite prend decidement trop de mesures hatives. Le calme et la circonspection ne sauraient nuire a aucun interet, pas meme a ceux de la respectable Corporation. Il faudrait autant que possible s'attacher a ne pas res- treindro la liberty des transactions, a ne pas tomber dans l'arbitraire et laisser les choses suivre leur cours naturel, d'autantplus que le fond de baisse est presque attaint et qn'en outre la crise ne frappe plus uniqueroent les Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie, mais s'dtend a tous les marches Strangers.

Le nombre des transactions en registries a ete de 64. La National Bank a cloture a 19 1/2-9/16 apres avoir fait 19 5/8. L'Agricole s'est tenue a 7 5,-8-11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a ramenee a 100 Faction ancienne et 110 la nouvelle, la Banque d'Athenes a 122, la Banque d'Orient a 120.
Le Credit Foncier a ete delaisse a 700; les obligations a lots anciennes sont revenues a 320 et les nouvelles a 268-269. La Daira a re­trograde a 14 et I'Union Fonetere /t 4 1/2.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelires, les Nungovich ont ete cotes 15 ex-coupon. Les Egyptian ont fini it 5 1/16 apres avoir ete traites au-dessus de 5 5/16. Les Excelsior sont tomb?s a2 1/4>
La Delta Land a ete bien tenue a 2. Les Estates ont cloture a £ 1. Les Constructions sont revenues a 0 7/16 et lesOnsis a 0 7,16-1/2.
Nous detachons d'une correspondance de Londres, en date du 9 Juin, le passage suivant :

" La situation du marche monetaire n est pas satisfnisante. On remarque trop d'exporta- tions d'or, et l'argent au lendemain est cher et difficile. Les Banques " ramassent '',a Paris surtout, par suite de la toumure inquietante que prennent de Russie.

" Au Stock Exchange, les transactions sont presque nulles en presence de la chert? de l'argent. Les capitalistes en quite de place­ments continuent a rester a l'ecart; seuls les baissiere sont en plein dans leur ?l?ment. L'inquietude et le malaise sont partout ; on s'attend a une bien mauvaise liquidation et a des chutes provoquees par les r?centes fail- lites. "
L'assemblie generale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. sera tenue au Caire samedi prochain, 22 Juin courant, a 4 h. p.m., a la National Bank of Egypt.

A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil d'ad- ministration ; presentation des comptes et bilan de l'exercice clos le 31- Mars 1907 ; fixa­tion du dividende ; election d'adininistrnteurs, etc. Le depot des titres doit etre effectur deux jours avant la date fixie pour l'assemblee.

Du rapport du conseil d'administration, qui vient d'etre publie, il resulte que la situation de la Societe est vraiment tris promettante. A la cloture de l'exercice ecoule, les proprietes de la Delta Land au Caire, Helouan, Tantah, Mansourah et divers autres centres de l'inti- rieur comprenaient unesuperficie de 1,561,699 metres carris, revenant a la somme de L.E. 179,055, sur laquelle la Societe n'a plus a payer que L.E. 28,258, total des montants non echus.
La Compagnie a, en outre, des participa­tions avec des tiers dans d'importantes ac­quisitions de terrains au Caire et en province.
Les benefices nets pour Fannie se montent a £ 35,540. Le conseil propose le paiement
d'un dividende de 3 sh. par action.
L'assemble general ordinaire de l'Egyptian Hotels-Oo. est convoquee au siege social a Londifes pour le ler Juillet prochain.
A l'ordri du jour : rapport do conseil d'ad- inisttion approbation des comptes etbilan l'exercice ecoule; fixation du dividende.
Le depot des titres en Egypte doit etre effect
tue, sept jours avant la date de l'assemblee a
la National Bank- of Egypt, A l'Anglo-Egj-pt'n'Bank ou A la Societe Generate Egyptienne.
Les cours du coton en Amerique sont ren-
seign's en hausse. Depuis vendredi passe, le Juillet a gagne 22 points a 11.61 et I'Octobro
11 points a II 41. Le disponible a, par contre,
reactionne de 25 points a 12 90.
Les arrivages a New-York, pour les deux
derniers jours de la semaine, ont ete de 11,000
balles contre 9,600.
Liverpool a cloture samedi a 6.65 et 6.37
contre 6.66 et 6.40 la veille.
Ici, le marche a ete, avant-hier, soutenn sur
lies achats du commerce. Le Juillet, qui avait
fini a 20 1/4, a ouvert ce matin a 20 3/32pour
cloturer A 20 1/8. Le Novembre, qui etait reste
A 20 1/32, a debute aujourd'hui a 19 7/8 pour
terminer A 19 31/32-20.

div.head:
CRISIS IN FRANCE
SERIOUS RIOTS
TROOPS OCCUPY NARBONNE

div.p: Three members of the wine-growers' committee at Argelliers have been arrested, but M. Albert and the others have disappeared. Gendarmes are searching for them everywhere. Yelling crowds stoned the infantry and cavalry escorting M. Ferroul to the station at Narbonne and were dispersed by cavalry charges

10,000 troops occupy Narbonne. The officers were hooted in the streets. Business is suspended as a sign of mourning. The mob in the evening attempted to fire on the sub-prefecture, but were dispersed by the troops after an hour and a half a scuffling and charges. (Renier)

The demonstration at Montpeilier last night culminated in an attempt to ignite the Court House and .in the stoning of a force of gendarmes, many of whom were severely injured. Troops were called out and dispersed the mob. The Cuirassiers at Narbonne were pelted with chairs and other missiles from the windows and were temporarily repulsed.
The rest of the wine-growers' committee have surrendered, except M. Albert.
Owing to events in the South the dinner at the Champs Elysées, and other festivities in King Chulalongkorns' honour which were rn have taken place here, have been abandoned. (Reuter)
M. Clemenceau announced to the Chamber that the troops were defending Narbonne and Montpellier against raiders. (Havas)
The demonstrators threw a police agent into the river and the troops fired on the crowd. Pour persons were killed, including one girl, and eleven wounded. (Havas)
M. Girard, chef de la sûreté, has been wounded. ( Havas)

div.head:
CHINESE FOREIGN MINISTER
DISMISSED FOR INCOMPETENCE

div.p: The "Times" learns from Peking that Chu- hungebi, who was regarded as the most incompetent Foreign Minister ever known, has been dismissed and replaced by Ruhaihuan, the Imperial Commissioner who signed the Mackay treaty in 1902. The appointment is welcomed. (Reuter)

div.head:
ENGLAND AND PERSIA
ATTACK ON CONSULATE

div.p: Salar-ed-Dowleh has taken refuge in the British Consulate at Kermanshah. (Reuter).

House of Common. Sir E Grey, replying to Major Austruther-Gray, said that the firing on the Britsh Consulate at Kermanshah had not been directed against the refugees. The Persian Government had expressed profound regret and had ordered the punishment of the guilty. (Reuter)
A torpedo-boat sank at Torquay after an explosion on board. The crew have been saved. (Reuter)
A madman threw a bomb at the Chamber of Deputies which did not explode. (Havas)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE
GERMANY'S PROPOSAL
Safety of Russian Delegates.

div.p: At the Conference Germany proposed the establishment of an International Prize Tribunal to settle difficulties arising from judgements given at the local prize courts. The United States supported the proposal.

The Russian Minister of Justice has telegraphed to the Dutch Minister of Justice that he had grave apprehensions for the safety of the Russian delegates. Elaborate precautions have consequently been taken and secret agents guard M. Nelidoff day ad night, A police barrack has been installed in the cellar of the conerence hall. The police are ready to rush in at the first alarm. The building is searched and all doors sealed after each sitting (Reuter).
Serious demonstrations occurred here today against the Premier in connection with the present absolutist regime. The police dispersed the crowd, killing two of them and wounding many. (Reuter)
Further disturbances took place today. Many arrests were made. There are no details to hand owing to the censorship. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE COTTON MARKET
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAMS WEEKLY REPORT

div.p: The demand for Egyptians on the spot continues very limited, and prices irregular. Quotations of Brown are raised 1/16 plb. and Uppers 1/8 d plb. for the week.

American Futures. The Market this week has been fairly active with frequent fluctuations but prices have generally had a declining tendency, todays closing values being 23 ½ points lower for old Crop, and 18 to 22 points lower for the New Crop positions, than those of last Thursday. The decline is chiefly due to a week of fine warm weather generally throughout the Cotton area, to liquidation by the "Bull" interest, an to some "Bear" manipulation. It is difficult to predict the course of the market; there must be a considerable long interest yet to be liquidated, but there will remain for some time a great sensitiveness to any unfavorable weather conditions, and it seems more than probable that we shall be liable to frequent sharp fluctuations; a continuance of fine warm weather might easily send prices down to 6d plb. or on the other hand any recurrence of unfavorable conditions would certainly cause renewed speculation, and a quick advance.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY
div.p: The following is an abstract of the report presented at the annual meeting held in Paris on June 4th :—

The traffic on the Canal, which diminished slightly in 1905, showed improvement in 1906, and slightly exceeded that of 1904, hitherto the record year. Thus, although the rate reduction which came into effect on January 1, 1906, involved a diminution in receipts of nearly 10 million francs, the actual decline is less than 6 millions, owing to the expansion in the traffic.

The cautious appropriations approved by the shareholders for 1904 and 1905 would have enabled us to face a less favourable position, and we have no hesitation in proposing to fix the dividend for 1906 at 141 francs net the same rate as for the two preceding years, while at the same time making large provision for statutory reserve and for amortisation funds.

The total receipts in 1906 amounted to 111,989,123francs, ora decline, as compared with 1905, of 5,319,074 francs. The loss on transit dues, amounting to 5,868,136 francs, has been reduced by about 550,000 francs owing to an increase in the subsidiary receipts of the Company. The total expanses amounted to 42,279,469 francs, including 4,000,000 franos for depreciation and 150,321 francs for insurance funds. This is an increase of 1,295,285 francs as compared with 1905, the greater part of which is due to expenditure on the maintenance of the Canal. The balance of receipts over expenditure is 69,709,653 francs—a decline of 6,614,359 francs as compared with 1905. Of this amount 3 per cent., or 2,091,290 francs, is set aside for statutory reserve, leaving a balance of 67,618,364 francs, to which must be added 15,673 francs brought forward, leaving a disposable total of 67,634,037 francs. In order to maintain t|ie net dividend of 141 francs it is proposed to withdraw 3,800,000 francs from the special reserve accumulated during the two previous years, raising the total amount available to 71,434,037 francs. Of this the dividend will absorb 71,377,465 francs, leaving 56,572 francs to be carried forward. It will be noticed that the appropriation from special reserve leaves intact more than half of that fund, and that the statutory reserve has been increased, part of which will ultimately be available for dividend purposes. Hence the position is such as to assure the continuance of the present rate of distribution.

During the year 1906 there passed through the Canal 3,975 vessels, representing a tonnage of 13,445,504 tons. As compared with 1905, this is a diminution of 141 vessels and an increase of 811,399 tons. The development, of the traffic in 1906 is, therefore, due exclusively to an increase in the average tonnage per vessel, which was particularly marked last year, the average tonnage rising from 3,191 tons in 1905 to 3,382 tons in 1906. An important modification has recently been introduced into the regulations with regard to the transit of tank petroleum steamers, which, though it did not come into eft'eot in 1906, ought to be mentioned. When the transit of such vessels was authorised in 1891 the Company confined the permission to the transport of refined pe troleum, and excluded raw petroleum and essences. Owing to the great importance which the development of tho motor-car industry has given to essenoes, and of their shipment in large quantities from the Dutch East Indies to Europe via the Cape of Good Hope, it has been found impossible to restrict them from passing through the Canal, and their transit will tie permitted in future, subject to such conditions as will avoid dangerous risks.

Both the Port Said and the Maritime Canals have been maintained in good navigable condi tion by dredging. A depth of 10.50 metres has been kept up, and at the end of 1906 there were only a few spots where the depth was as little as 9.50 meties. As after the execution of the works projected this year the former figure will be attained or exceeded throughout the entire length of the Canal, it has been decided to extend the maximum draught of vessels to 8.53 metres (28 feet English), the present maximum being 8.23 metres (27 feet English).
A third dredge has been ordered, of the same type as that supplied in 1905, which will be one of the most important in existence.

Improvements were actively oarried on in 1906, including the construction of new basins on the Asian bank for petroleum and coal vessels, the enlargement of the Cherif basin, the reconstruction and lengthening of the East jetty and the creation of new basins for the general works. Other new schemes of importance will be begun shortly, which must necessarily take several years, but which will be completed as soon as possible.

As stated in the last report, the repatriation of Russian troops from Manchuria contributed to an appreciable extent to swell the receipts during the earlier months of 1906. There were employed on this service 71 vessels,with a tonnage of about 267,000 tons, which car ried more than 120,000 men. After this spe- uial transit was over traffic fell to a more normal level, but it was continuously active during the remainder of the year. The Indian harvest of 1905-06 led to the expectation that the exports would lead to an import trade of magnitude. This anticipation wits not realised, but there was great expansion in tho growth of shipmentsfrora Europe to the regions beyond Suez, thus affording further proof of the diversify of your traffics, and the way in which loss in one direction is counterbalanced gain in another. The great extension recently of postal navigation, and of regular servioes cargo-boats, also contributed largely to successful results of last year, results which have even been improved upon in 1907. Many ships have passed through the Canal from north to south in search of freight at Asiatic ports, and their return, which is not yet over has helped to keep things active. Generally king, the situation may be regarded as satisfactory.

The directors greatly regret the loss last January of their colleague, M. Julien Lefebvre, who joined the Council in 1888, and had not ceased, in spite of his great age, to work assiduously on behalf of the Company. More recently the death of M. Casimir-Perier has bad to be deplored. As member and as Vice- President of the Council he gave the Company the benefit of his great experience and of his eminent authority. We have appointed M. Denis Peron.se, formerly inspector general of bridges and roads, and member of the Works Consultative Committee since 1893, to succeed M. Lefebvre, and M. Lépjne in place ofM. Casimir Perier. We ask yon to confirm these nominations, and to roelect the fonr retiring directors, MM. R. Guichard and C. Jonnart, ice-Admiral Humann, and Lord Rothmore. Appended to the full report, which may be obtained on application at the Company's office, 9 Rue Charras, Paris, are the usual statistical tables. These include particulars of tonnage and receipts during the last 30 years ; classification of the vessels using the Canal 1905, showing the proportion of the total traffic due to the various countries and to the principal shipping companies ; and the number of passengers carried through the Canal in each of the last 30 years, besides various other particulars.

div.head: THE MADNESS OF THE ENGLISHMAN
div.p: All over the worldyou meet the Englishman, and wherever you find him, he seems always to be engaged, like some flagellant monk, in inflicting pain upon himself. You meet him, says the "County Gentleman," half-fainting under the tropical sun in Africa forests plagued by flies, tormented by thirst, needlessly running the risk of attack by wild beasts; or you may see him tossed on the furious seas in his yacht, his lips cracked with salt, his eyes half-blinded by driving rain. On almost inaccessible mountains, on ice-floes, on burning deserts, it is always the same. Wherever you meet the mad Englishmanhe is in difficulties or looking for them ; and he looks at you from under his sun-helmet, or out of his furs and remarks, with an inane grin: "isnt it rippin?" Such he is abroad; and behold, when you seek him in his home, expecting to see him at least fairly rational there, you probably find him floundering in the early hours of the morning in a six-foot tank of cold water.

div.head: THE PAN-ISLAMIC MOVEMENT
div.p: SHEIKH KIDWAI'S SPEECH

Sir Charles Elliott presided at the farewell dinner given on Tuesday week, at the Carlton Hotel, to Sheikh Mushir Hossain Kidwai, hon. secretary of the Pan-Islamic Society, on the occasion of his return to India. Dr. B. Wahby (Egypt) was among those present.
The toast of "Shaikh Mushir Hossain Kidwai of Gadia" was proposed by Mr. A. Billal Quilliam, on behalf of the society, and by the Divan Badri Nath, on behalf of friends.

Sheikh M. H. Kidwai, in reply, said that he should always have the happiest recollections of that gathering, which seemed to be rather a religious conference than a farewell dinner. Every great religion of the world was represented at the tables. There were people of different colours and races—from Turkey, Persia, Egypt, South Africa, Portuguese India, and India. It was this kind of common fraternity that Pan- Islamists wanted to establish all over the world. Sir Auckland Colvin recently wrote ta him that religion in its essence was "disruptive and alienistic but he was a Musulman because he believed that Islam's greatest object was to establish a universal brotherhood withont any distinction of colour, or race, or position, or sex, or age, or country, and he had become a Pan-Islamist because he believed that the spread of these essential Islamic principles would remove the most unhappy, disruptive, and alienistic tendencies of the modern age—the race, colour, and country prejudices. This society was disruptive in no way. It had been his constant desire that the English people should have friendly relations with the Muslims, and that England should be a kind of guide towards the way to progress on modem lines for the Muslim dominions. He had been trying not only to remove the prejudices of the Christian people towards the Musulmans, but also to unite Jews with Muslims, and he went so far as an urge that, in India, Musulmans should not by any means let their friendly relations with Hindus be disturbed even though they suffered political loss. They called themselves Pan-Islamists, not because they aimed at any political aggrandisement or territorial expansion of Islam, but because they wanted to spread the Islamic principles and because they wanted to regenerate Musulmails. He wished to impress on the minds of his co-religionists of Egypt and also upon his Hindu brethren in India, that the future prosperity of a nation did not depend so much upon territorial possessions or political achievements, as upon industrial and commercial advancement. The Musulmans of the world and the Hindus of India must realize fully the fact, that their regeneration was impossible unless they and their countries progressed economically and financially in commerce and industry. It was not only Muslins who failed to realize the importance of this point. Even English statesmen did not pay due attention to it. Germany had realized it, and had abstained from going into de niQifstrations against Turkey. She had encouraged Morocco, and, in fact, saved that country from the hands of France. Why ? Only to win the good will of the people of those countries, and thus make them her good customers. We should lose India commercially if we exasperated the people of that country. The sWord could not in these days secure customers; good customers should be conciliated and humoured, not insulted as in South Africa, or irritated as in India, Turkey, and Morocco. In conclusion, he expressed the hope that he might come back to England to further the Mosque and the Anglo-Muslim friendship club schemes. (Cheers.)
Other toasts included the Sultan of Turkey, and the Khedive of Egypt.

div.head: ELECTRICITY IN TURKEY
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce of Turkey's forwarded to the Manchester Chamber of Commerce a statement regarding the probable extension in the near future of the electrical industry in the Ottoman Empire.

English contractors should, it is pointed out, take steps to place themselves in a position to tender when necessary. The number of electrical installations in Turkey is steadily in creasing, and the Government contemplate electrically lighting the capital and other cities and also undertaking the supply of power for the tramways. It is suggested that contractors and electrical firms in Great Britain should appoint agents in Constantinople and be prepared to send experts to Turkey whenever necessary This is the practice of German and Belgian electricians, and the former have hitherto obtained most of the contracts for the electrical undertakings. If British contractors will take the same steps they should be able to secure fair amount of business. It is reported that there is at present some disposition on the part of the Ottoman Government to favour British enterprises.

The secretary for the North of England of the British Chamber (Mr. George Thomas), who makes the communication, will be pleased to obtain any further information which may be desired by firms interested.
